Award.AwardTitle: A Breakthrough Nanolithography Technique Using 'Electro-Fountain Pens'

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a manufacturing process for producing complex nanoscale circuits for future electronics and other applications by "writing" with electrically activated nano-tip "fountain pens". The process, termed "electro-fountain pen (EFP) lithography", takes advantage of electromigration-induced flow of liquid metal, and enables continuous writing of nanoscale patterns with a metallic liquid for making high quality electrical circuits. The technique eliminates the main drawback of current tip-based lithography techniques by being able to continuously deliver the writing material to the tip without the need for frequent replenishment. Because the flow is driven electrically, EFP lithography may be used to continuously transport not only metallic liquids via electromigration, but also non-metallic liquids by electrophoresis. The planned effort will develop the tool, optimize the conditions for laying down adherent patterns of several materials on different substrates, and study the physics of liquid electromigration and its dependence on material and process parameters.

If successful, the benefit to society of this research will include the development of a new nano-manufacturing process, which may eventually lead to commercialization. The process has the potential to be a new and effective method for making complex nano-patterns on substrates for applications ranging from electronics to sensors to bio-molecular assaying, and is therefore likely to have significant impact on the nation?s manufacturing base. In addition, this effort will integrate research and education by advancing discovery and understanding by graduate students. Undergraduate students will participate in the research through the Research Experience for Undergraduates program, and high school interns will be hired to assist with the aim of attracting them to engineering. Results of the project will be broadly disseminated through faculty and student participation at meetings of learned societies and grantees' conferences of the Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation division of NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to develop a manufacturing process for writing micro to nanoscale patterns on a substrate by flowing a liquid metal down a tip or stylus by electromigration. Under optimal conditions, the process enables continuous writing of nanoscale patterns with a metallic liquid for making electrical circuits.  A tool based on a nano-positioning stage, a write-head and a heated sample stage enclosed in a vacuum system was developed, and this was used to produce sub-micron scale patterns on conductive substrates by thermal etching or liquid electromigration. The research developed (a) a fundamental understanding of the phenomenon of liquid electromigration, (b) a theoretical basis for writing patterns using a tip under an applied electric field, and (c) experimental conditions for writing using electrically activated thermal etching or liquid electromigration.

        The specific tasks accomplished included: (i) development of an apparatus for electrically-activated writing or liquid-metal deposition using a tip, (ii) investigation of the role of surface roughness on the transition from continuous to discontinuous (or beaded) liquid flow, and (iii) study of the conditions under which liquid metals flow along or against the direction of the applied electric field. The experimental apparatus and an example of a line drawn on a metallic substrate are shown in the accompanying figures.

         Journal papers, book chapters and conference papers were produced based on this work. The team collaborated with Indian Institute of Science on part of the project.  Several seminars were given by the PI at universities and national laboratories on liquid electromigration and electrically activated writing.

         Graduate student Ms. Yang Li did her M.S. work, and graduate student Mr. Ben Luce is continuing his PhD work based on this project.  Three postdoctoral associates (Uttara Sahaym, Zhe Chen and Lutz Meinshausen) assisted the graduate students and conducted independent work on this project. Three undergraduate students (Sean Seekins, Matthew Gerboth and Ben Luce) also worked on this project during summers and/or academic year, and were trained on metallographic sample preparation, microscopy, design of electrical and vacuum equipment, and digital control and data acquisition.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this research was to develop a manufacturing process for writing micro to nanoscale patterns on a substrate by flowing a liquid metal down a tip or stylus by electromigration. Under optimal conditions, the process enables continuous writing of nanoscale patterns with a metallic liquid for making electrical circuits. A tool based on a nano-positioning stage, a write-head and a heated sample stage enclosed in a vacuum system was developed, and this was used to produce sub-micron scale patterns on conductive substrates by thermal etching or liquid electromigration. The research developed (a) a fundamental understanding of the phenomenon of liquid electromigration, (b) a theoretical basis for writing patterns using a tip under an applied electric field, and (c) experimental conditions for writing using electrically activated thermal etching or liquid electromigration. The specific tasks accomplished included: (i) development of an apparatus for electrically-activated writing or liquid-metal deposition using a tip, (ii) investigation of the role of surface roughness on the transition from continuous to discontinuous (or beaded) liquid flow, and (iii) study of the conditions under which liquid metals flow along or against the direction of the applied electric field. The experimental apparatus and an example of a line drawn on a metallic substrate are shown in the accompanying figures. Journal papers, book chapters and conference papers were produced based on this work. The team collaborated with Indian Institute of Science on part of the project. Several seminars were given by the PI at universities and national laboratories on liquid electromigration and electrically activated writing. Graduate student Ms. Yang Li did her M.S. work, and graduate student Mr. Ben Luce is continuing his PhD work based on this project. Three postdoctoral associates (Uttara Sahaym, Zhe Chen and Lutz Meinshausen) assisted the graduate students and conducted independent work on this project. Three undergraduate students (Sean Seekins, Matthew Gerboth and Ben Luce) also worked on this project during summers and/or academic year, and were trained on metallographic sample preparation, microscopy, design of electrical and vacuum equipment, and digital control and data acquisition.
